title: DWP Universal Credit fraud probes double in three months as thousands hit by scam
text:

The government has doubled its number of Universal Credit fraud probes in just three months after thousands of genuine claimants fell victim to a scam.

A staggering 85,000 suspected frauds involving "advance" payments have now been referred to a dedicated unit - up from 42,000 in July.

Thousands of those hit are having to pay back any money they gained - and barely any of them have been moved back onto the old benefit system.

It comes after the BBC revealed fraudsters had conned struggling families into applying for Universal Credit in order to get cash from the Department for Work and Pensions.

Claimants split the money with con artists, only to find out it was an "advance payment" loan - which has to be paid back to the DWP in full over 12 months.

Those hit were then also stuck on Universal Credit, as opposed to the old "legacy" benefit system, without any transition payments.

(Image: E+)

(Image: Getty Images)

DWP Permanent Secretary Peter Schofield confirmed the number of probes has risen "week by week" in a hearing before the Commons Work and Pensions Committee.

He said a special team is now examining "around 85,000" cases where "staff felt there was a case of fraud being committed".

It is not known how many of those suspected cases involved someone being duped by a con artist, compared to how many were deliberately deceiving the DWP.

Mr Schofield said fraud referrals have dropped by two-thirds "immediately" after the DWP introduced new safeguards on September 18 - which mean claimants must now have visited a Jobcentre to get an advance.

He added extra changes are planned later in year “to further clamp down on this”.

(Image: PA)

More than 1,400 benefit claimants have been interviewed under caution and many are having to repay any funds they gained.

DWP officials have said:

If you were paid the full advance into your bank account through fraud and kept it all, you will need to pay the full amount back.

If you were paid the full advance into your bank account through fraud and the scammer took a cut, you will need to pay back the portion you kept.

If the scammer was paid the full advance into a bank account and gave you a cut, you will need to pay the cut back.

Despite previous pledges, Mr Schofield admitted "very few" victims have been taken off Universal Credit and returned to the legacy benefit system.

He did not give an exact figure but claimed some were better off under Universal Credit.

MPs sounded the alarm over the rise in fraud allegations. Work and Pensions Committee chairman Frank Field called it a "very serious case".

(Image: UK Parliament)

Tory MP Derek Thomas said a "perfectly innocent" student was left in "considerable debt" after suffering the scam and she is now "in a really difficult place".

Labour MP Ruth George said one claimant in poverty with several children had been left £120 a week worse off. She added: "They have been duped.

"They have been told they're applying for a loan. They've had someone looking like an official with a DWP badge turn up at their house and take their details from them.

"These are not people who have knowingly made a claim to Universal Credit."
description: The number of advance payment fraud referrals has exploded from 42,000 to 85,000 since July after an industrial-scale scam
